No. The weight of a volume of material is determined by its density. The density of steel beams is much higher than the density of dust particles, which means that for the same volume, steel beams would be much heavier than dust particles. The weight of a material is also related to its mass, which is a measure of its amount. Different units of mass are used for different purposes. In everyday life, mass is often expressed in terms of weight, such as "I weigh 150 pounds". However, this does not mean that weight is the same as mass. The strength of gravity makes weight a more suitable measure of mass for most everyday purposes. One pound (or one kilogram) is the unit of mass. Different units are used for different purposes or jurisdictions: the gram (or kilogram), used in most parts of the world; and the pound (or kilogram) used in some parts of the United States. 

1 pound of steel beams and 2 pounds of dust are the same weight, but they are different masses because the steel beams have more material in the same volume than the dust particles. The weight of a material can also be expressed in terms of "force", the force necessary to hold it still in a gravitational field. For example, "the weight of a 10 kilogram rock is 100 newtons". However, this will not work where the gravitational field is non-zero. It is also impractical, because the mass of a material is a fixed (usually constant) property, which does not change much, even after it is moved. The gravity strength at a location is relatively variable and non-constant. Thus, the weight of a material is mostly determined by gravity.
